abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Sector Adjustment
            Program Project for Honduras were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was uncertain, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            deficient. Some lessons learned included: adapting
            successful models from other countries can be extremely
            helpful in preparing a reform program and the Bank is well
            placed to facilitate this kind of cross-country transfer of
            knowledge and experience. In this case, the Chilean
            Electricity Law, enacted in 1982, served as a sound basis on
            which the Honduran Electricity Law was designed. Adjustment
            lending aims to support both structural reforms and to
            alleviate the country's balance of payments
            constraints, with the latter often requiring relatively
            quick disbursements. Consequently, major conditions should
            be required up front (i.e. for Board presentation), and a
            few others (aimed at making the program sustainable) for the
            release of not more than a second tranche. If it is foreseen
            that the complexity of the sector adjustment requires a
            longer implementation period, it will be advisable to
            explore options for doing it through more than one lending
            operation, over perhaps a longer period of time. A Contract
            Plan (or Performance Contract) between the Government and a
            Government-owned power utility, may not be an effective
            mechanism for improving the operational and financial
            performance of the sector or the utility. It may be more
            appropriate to concentrate efforts on reducing the role and
            monopoly status of the public utility and correspondingly
            increasing the participation of the private sector. This, in
            fact, is the Government's present policy, with its plan
            to privatize ENEE's distribution functions.
